Award.AwardTitle: Learning from Unanticipated Scientific Security Research Results Workshop

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Computer science, and computer security in particular, tends to learn from our successes and ignore our failures. The workshop series Learning from Unanticipated Scientific Security Research Results
(LUSSRR) addresses this limitation. Through this series of workshops, researchers present their unexpected results - which may be failures, but may also be opportunities to learn something other than what was expected. This process encourages researchers to learn from each other and avoid duplication of effort, while encouraging new approaches to old problems. LUSSRR workshops publish proceedings which are included in the traditional digital libraries such as IEEE and ACM.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Learning from Authoritative Security Experiment Results (LASER)

NSF Grant 1143766 Outcomes Report

January 22, 2016

 

The Learning from Authoritative Security Experiment Results (LASER) workshop seeks to foster a dramatic change in the paradigm of cyber security research and experimentation by promoting more scientific methodologies in cyber security research. The workshop focuses on papers that demonstrate good overall experimental design but may have negative results (i.e., the hypothesis was refuted) and on papers that reproduce the results obtained by other researchers. In addition to providing a forum for the publication of such papers, the workshop aims to create a community around conducting sound experiments and educating researchers in both how to conduct experiments and effectively present results. Under this grant, LASER organizers planned and conducted three workshops, which were held in July 2012, October 2013, and October 2014.

 

The 2012 LASER workshop accepted six papers which were presented at the workshop and published through the ACM Digital Journal. The workshop also featured two invited talks (“Ignorance: How it Drives Science” by Stuart Firestein and “Concrete actions to improve the level of science currently observed in the security community” by Roy Maxion) plus a number of relevant panel and group discussions. The workshop was attended by 47 people. More information on the workshop can be found at http://2012.laser-workshop.org.

 

The 2013 LASER workshop accepted four of thirteen submitted papers which were presented at the workshop and published through USENIX. USENIX supports open access to scholarly papers. The workshop selected four additional papers for “works-in-progress” sessions during which authors received expert feedback on how to make the work more rigorous and more scientifically sound. The workshop also featured two invited talks ("Confessions of a Privacy Economist" by Dr. Alessandro Acquisti and "The Higgs Boson: Discovery, Certainty and Uncertainty" by Dr. Seth Zenz) and a panel ("Rerun-ability, Repeatability and Reproducability in Experimentation", with Roy Maxion, Terry Benzel and Lance Joneckis). A number of the presentations were filmed and are available for viewing on the 2013 LASER website. Attendance was impacted due to a government shutdown with only 33 people attending. A last minute effort to live stream the workshop gained 36 additional participants, who viewed one or more individual sessions. More information on the workshop can be found at http://2013.laser-workshop.org.

 

The 2014 LASER workshop accepted two of twelve submitted papers which were presented at the workshop and published through USENIX. Three additional papers were accepted for “works-in-progress” sessions. The workshop also featured four invited talks ("Operationalizing Science" by Deb Frincke; "Why Does Reproducibility in Computational Science Deserve Our Attention?" by Victoria Stodden; “Statistics Done Wrong: Pitfalls in Experimentation” by Alex Reinhart, and “Experiment Design” by Roy Maxion), a discussion session (“What Does it Mean to Do Science, and Are We Doing it?” facilitated by John McHugh, and a panel discussion ("How Did We Get Into This Mess, and How Will We Get Out", with Sami Saydjari and Shing-hon Lau).  A number of the presentations were filmed and are available for viewing on the 2014 LASER website. The workshop was attended by 29 people, plus another 28 who viewed one or more individual live-streaming sessions. More information on the workshop may be found at http://2014.laser-workshop.org.

Outreach efforts were increased in 2014 with LASER organizers reaching out to potential participants via social media. A Twitter @LASER_Workshop account was established along with a LinkedIn professional group (https://www.linkedin.com/groups/8116696). A mailing list (http://www.laser-workshop.org/mailing-list/) was also established so that interested parties can subscribe for workshop n...
